history.content: It is highly recommended to take 126/127 before or with 189. If you havent taken a multivariable class before than you should take 53 otherwise a high school dual enrollment/ccc class should suffice, but if you are going to take it anyways you may as well get a grade for it. Taking 126 asap and with 174/127/53 sounds like a good move. If you want to go into research/do well in cs189, I would put off cs170 for now

It is highly recommended to take 126/127 before or with 189. If you havent taken a multivariable class before than you should take 53 otherwise a high school dual enrollment/ccc class should suffice, but if you are going to take it anyways you may as well get a grade for it. Taking 126 asap and with 174/127/53 sounds like a good move.

children.subject: I wouldn't say you "need" any of them. It's just that having taken classes like 127 and 126 allows you to focus on the higher-level concepts being taught in 189 rather than getting lost in the mathematical derivations. If you can self-study some of the material from 126/127 you'd probably be fine, although if you have the time, taking the courses is highly encouraged.

I would say math 53 level multivariable calculus, math 54 level linear algebra, and CS 70 level probability is the minimum requirement.

If you have taken math 110/eecs 127 level linear algebra, EECS 126 level probability, some advanced matrix calculus classed, it makes cs 189 much easier

170 is a pretty popular 1st upper division CS; you really only need big O from 61B and proof writing/thinking from 70. For 189, I'm assuming you're talking about next semester's Sahai offering? (It's a radically different class Fall v. Spring). Math 53 is overkill -- can you 1) take a partial derivative 2) apply the chain rule 3) visualize functions in multiple variables? Then you're set imo. The real beast is the linear algebra; you will need a SOLID grasp on linear algebra. 16b is a must, would def recommend 127 not even for the content which is just assumed in 189 but for the practice. Lastly, for the probability 174 is probably sufficient though 126 was one of the best classes I've taken at Berkeley (shoutout Kannan).

<md>but kannan doesn't teach it next semester :(
</md>
So would you say I need both all 4 of 126, 127, 53 and 174 to do well in 189? Or did you mean one of the options for any of those?

history.content:
I’m really looking forward to taking a couple of upper div CS classes: 170 and 189. I will be done with 61A/B/70 after this semester. Can I take 170 immediately after? I took 70 about a year ago so are there any topics to review from that class?

Then, for 189, I really wanted to take an ML class but I saw the prereq for Math 53. Since it’s not a major requirement, I wasn’t planning to take Math 53. Is it really necessary for 189 or is it possible to self study the relevant parts (if so what parts should I self study)? I know I can petition for UD credit but I would prefer to take a CS class in that spot anyways. Additionally, there is a recommendation for a class like 126. Would a class like CS174 cover this? Is a probability requirement like 126 really necessary for the class?

For reference I will be done with 61a/b/70 and ee16a/b.
history.subject: Couple of questions about upper division classes (170 and 189 mainly)
